G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting plan order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and upon a determination that the modification is in the best interests of the child.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting plan order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and upon a determination that the modification is in the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly cites G. L. c. 208, § 28 and explains that a Probate Court judge may modify a prior custody judgment upon finding a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then applies this two-part standard to the facts, affirming the existence of a material change and evaluating best interests, thereby squarely supporting the proposition about Massachusetts law on modification of custody/parenting plans.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ See Hartog v. Hartog, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 124, 128 (1989), and cases cited.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A child’s best interests are the paramount concern when crafting or modifying custody arrangements.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody decisions the best interests of the child are the paramount concern and interprets the governing statute to require that removal be in the child’s best interests. The court’s balancing of factors—custodial parent’s interests, noncustodial parent’s visitation, and the child’s needs—is expressly anchored in this best-interests standard, so the case directly supports the proposition that a child’s best interests are paramount when crafting or modifying custody arrangements.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute…provides that…[a child] shall not…be removed out of this commonwealth…unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 493 (2012.proposition: The relocation of a parent, which results in a disruptive impact on the child’s health, education, or well-being, constitutes a significant change in circumstances that can justify a modification of a parenting time order.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 493 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, parentage, and an initial best-interests custody determination, not modification of an existing parenting time order based on relocation. While the court discusses the harmful effects of the custodial parent’s move (Oregon/Michigan) on the child and factors like stability and disruption of attachment, it does so within an original custody award, not in the context of a ‘significant change in circumstances’ standard for modifying parenting time. Therefore, it does not establish the specific proposition about relocation constituting a change in circumstances justifying modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 493 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Jill had developed a strong emotional bond with Hunter… after which Rose moved her to Oregon… and, in doing so, disrupted Jill’s attachment to Hunter… The judge also found that Rose decided to move to Oregon and accepted employment in Michigan, to begin in July, ‘with little, if any, regard for [Jill’s] basic and fundamental needs.’… The judge found that a move to Michigan would put Jill ‘in an unfamiliar environment with new caregivers and… medical providers’ while Rose worked ‘extraordinary long hours as a medical resident.’”

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 474 (2016)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.proposition: The relocation of a parent, which results in a disruptive impact on the child’s health, education, or well-being, constitutes a significant change in circumstances that can justify a modification of a parenting time order.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about credit card fraud, identity fraud, and receiving stolen property. It does not involve family law, parenting time, child relocation, or modification of custody/parenting orders. Nothing in the court’s reasoning addresses changes in circumstances arising from a parent’s relocation or their impact on a child, so it cannot support the cited proposition.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant was convicted by a Superior Court jury of two counts of credit card fraud over $250 ... two counts of identity fraud ... one count of receiving stolen property ... and one count of attempted credit card fraud.... We thus affirm the credit card convictions.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 102, 110 (2.proposition: Transporting a child on lengthy, burdensome car trips that interfere with school performance and adequate rest has been recognized as contrary to the best interests of a child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 102, 110 (2.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about payments to witnesses, sufficiency of the evidence, prosecutorial argument, and joint venture instructions. It does not involve child custody, visitation, or any discussion of car travel burdens, school performance, or a child’s best interests. The proposition about lengthy, burdensome car trips being contrary to a child’s best interests is unrelated to any issue addressed in this decision.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (2002.proposition: Courts may also modify a parenting schedule when a parent's inflexible insistence on implementing damaging arrangements shows disregard for the child's best interests.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (2002.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute, not about modifying a parenting schedule between parents based on one parent’s inflexible or harmful arrangements. The court discusses best interests, parental autonomy, harm to the child, and the standards for grandparent visitation, but it does not address modification of a parenting schedule due to a parent’s insistence on damaging arrangements. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (2002.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, operating with the guidance of the Troxel case and our case law in related areas, and law from other jurisdictions, the traditional best interests considerations… can, and should, be construed to fit the statute’s context and, thereby, satisfy due process… To obtain visitation, the grandparents must rebut the presumption… to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm…”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.proposition: Plaintiff’s request to eliminate the midweek overnight and adjust the weekend schedule is a reasonable modification that seeks to prioritize Emily’s health, academic performance, and overall well-being, consistent with the caselaw affirming the importance of a stable, supportive environment for children.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.support_reasoning: The case is about restricting a noncustodial parent’s religious instruction during visitation, not about adjusting the timing or structure of visitation (such as eliminating a midweek overnight) for health, academics, or general well-being. The SJC reverses a restriction on visitation for lack of proof of harm and emphasizes the importance of frequent contact with both parents, and warns against limiting visitation based on speculative or inadequately supported claims of detriment. It does not endorse schedule modifications like the one described, nor does it frame such changes as presumptively reasonable to promote stability; it instead requires detailed proof of substantial injury to the child before materially limiting visitation.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.relevant_excerpt: “However, harm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail… It is often said that if accommodation appears necessary, that form should be sought which intrudes least on the religious inclinations of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights.”

Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.raw_text: Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 558 (1980)
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.proposition: Plaintiff’s request to eliminate the midweek overnight and adjust the weekend schedule is a reasonable modification that seeks to prioritize Emily’s health, academic performance, and overall well-being, consistent with the caselaw affirming the importance of a stable, supportive environment for children.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.support_reasoning: The case focuses on standards for modifying custody—requiring a change in circumstances and prioritizing the child’s welfare, including the benefit of a stable, satisfactory home with a proven primary custodian. It does not address specific visitation schedule adjustments, midweek overnights, or academic/health-based modifications to parenting time. While it affirms the general importance of a stable and supportive environment, it does not provide authority for the particular proposition that eliminating a midweek overnight and adjusting weekends is a reasonable modification for those reasons.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.relevant_excerpt: “Although it may in fact be true that Raymond also offers a happy environment for Joshua, the evidence demonstrates that it is not a ‘settled home’… This ‘militates against [Raymond’s] becoming the capable custodian of [Joshua] which [Michele] has already proven to be.’ … In sum, there is nothing in the record before us that would warrant removing the child from a caring mother and a ‘home environment which appears to be quite satisfactory.’ We conclude, therefore, that the welfare of the child would be best served by having custody remain in Michele…”
